Given: Aeroplane mass at start-up 3663 lbs, Aviation gasoline (density 6 lbs/gal)-fuel load 74 gal, Take-off altitude sea level, Headwind 40 kt, Cruising altitude 8000 ft, Power setting full throttle 2300 RPM 20°C lean of peak EGT. Calculate the ground range.

Refer to figure. 
 (For this question use CAP 697 Figure 4.5.2) Describe how to convert nautical ground miles (NGM) into nautical air miles (NAM).

options.text: Use the TAS to enter the graph. Travel horizontally left to the actual wind component. Travel vertically to the appropriate ground distance line, and finally travel horizontally to read the nautical air miles.
Enter from the bottom of the graph using the zero-wind reference line. Travel vertically to the appropriate ground distance line and finally move horizontally to read the nautical miles.

Use the air distance to enter the graph. Travel horizontally to the appropriate ground distance line.Travel vertically to intersect the wind component, and finally travel horizontally to read the nautical air miles.

Use the TAS to enter the graph. Travel horizontally to the zero wind reference line. Travel vertically to the appropriate ground distance line, and finally travel horizontally to read the nautical air miles.

Integrated range curves or tables are presented in the Aeroplane Operations Manuals. Their purpose is:

options.text: to determine the fuel consumption for a certain still air distance considering the decreasing fuel flow with decreasing mass.
to determine the flight time for a certain leg under consideration of temperature deviations.
to determine the optimum speed considering the fuel cost as well as the time related cost of the aeroplane.
to determine the still air distance for wind components varying with altitude.

Contingency Fuel plus Final Reserve Fuel.

variant.question:
Refer to figure 033-134. Consider a twin engine piston aircraft at cruising altitude. Given that: - Altitude: 20 000 ft - Maintaining constant indicated airspeed: 90 kt - Weight: 6 000 lbs - Fuel remaining: 1 000 lbs - Average wind: 10 kt tail Assuming:
  • That the aircraft weight will reduce as it burns fuel - The reduction in fuel flow with weight is linear with time - ISA conditions - IAS = CAS
What is the approximate maximum range based on the maximum endurance?

Refer to figure.Consider a twin engine piston aircraft at cruising altitude. Determine the aircraft's fuel flow, given the following:
Altitude: 20 000 ftIndicated airspeed: 100 ktWeight: 6 000 lbs
Comparing the integrated range and the average fuel flow procedure, which of the following statement is correct?

options.text: The integrated range procedure is more accurate and reflects the different fuel flows during different phases of flight.
The average fuel flow procedure is more accurate and reflects the fuel consumption during different phases of flight.
The integrated range procedure is easier and faster when determining fuel even for long range flights.
The average fuel flow procedures allow an accurate monitoring of fuel even for long range flights.

variant.question:
A route is planned to MALMO Sturup Airport, via the hold overhead the STURUP SUP VOR / DME.
The total ground distance from TOC to SUP is 261 NM and the maximum Take-off fuel is 175 Kg.
Given the following information, what is the maximum fuel available for holding before starting the approach?
Planned fuel from Take-off to TOC: 24 Kg
Fuel planned for the approach at MALMO: 11 Kg
Min Landing Fuel (ignore other reserves): 22 Kg
Average GS from TOC to SUP: 158 kts
Average fuel flow from TOC to SUP: 57 kg / h.

During cruise flight, the FMS generates an alert that you have 0.3 tonnes less fuel than required to reach your destination.
Under NORMAL circumstances, which fuel should remain upon arrival at your destination?

options.text: Alternate fuel plus final reserve fuel.
Alternate fuel plus contingency fuel plus final reserve fuel.

variant.question:
For a flight of 2800 ground nautical miles the following apply:Head wind component: 20 kt  
  Temperature: ISA + 15°C  
  Brake release mass: 64700 kgThe a trip fuel, and b trip time respectively are
When planning a flight according to the predetermined point procedure, what is the minimum amount of fuel that a turbine-engined aircraft needs to carry? The greater of

options.text:
1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least 2 hours at cruise consumption above the destination and not less than final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the destination alternate + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft above alternate elevation and not less than final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, fuel to destination alternate, final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the alternate + contingency, fuel from alternate back to destination, final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to predetermined point via destination, trip fuel from predetermined point to alternate, final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to predetermined point via alternate, trip fuel from predetermined point to destination, final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, additional fuel if required for at least 45 min + 15% of flight time at cruising level or 2 hours, whichever is less and not less than final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the destination alternate + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least fuel to fly for 45 minutes and not less than final reserve fuel

variant.question: When planning a flight according to the predetermined point procedure, what is the minimum amount of fuel that a piston-engined aircraft needs to carry? The greater of

options.text:
1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, additional fuel if required for at least 45 min + 15% of flight time at cruising level or 2 hours, whichever is less and not less than final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the destination alternate + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least fuel to fly for 45 minutes and not less than final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to predetermined point via destination, trip fuel from predetermined point to alternate, final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to predetermined point via alternate, trip fuel from predetermined point to destination, final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least 2 hours at cruise consumption above the destination and not less than final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the destination alternate + contingency, additional fuel if required but at least 30 minutes at holding speed at 1 500 ft above alternate elevation and not less than final reserve fuel

1. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to destination + contingency, fuel to destination alternate, final reserve fuel
2. Taxi fuel, trip fuel to the alternate + contingency, fuel from alternate back to destination, final reserve fuel

For this question consider Flight Planning Manual MRJT 1 Figures 4.5.2 and 4.5.3.1.
 
The MRJT Integrated Range Tables as shown in Fig 4.5.3.1 require sector distance in NAM.
Which statement is INCORRECT concerning the calculation of NAM?

options.text:
If given a sector distance (NGM), NAM can be calculated
using the formula:  NAM = NGM x (GS / TAS)

If given a sector distance (NGM), the graph at Figure
4.5.2 may be used to calculate NAM

If given a sector time, NAM can be calculated using the
formula:  NAM = TAS x Time

If given a sector distance (NGM), NAM can be calculated
using the formula:  NAM = NGM x (TAS / GS)

 During pre-flight planning you decide that NO alternate aerodrome/heliport is required for your flight. During cruise an in-flight fuel check reveals that the fuel consumption is higher than planned. What is the minimum amount of fuel required on arrival at the destination aerodrome/heliport?

A flight is conducted to an isolated destination aerodrome. The required usable fuel at the Predetermined Point (PDP) to continue the flight towards the destination aerodrome should be at least equal to the total of the Trip Fuel from the PDP to the destination, plus...

options.text: Contingency Fuel from the PDP to the destination aerodrome, and Additional Fuel in accordance with the use of the isolated aerodrome procedure.
Final Reserve Fuel and any Extra Fuel at the discretion of the commander.
Contingency Fuel from the departure aerodrome to the destination aerodrome, and Additional Fuel in accordance with the PDP procedure.
Additional Fuel in accordance with the use of the isolated aerodrome procedure.

- Average TAS: 450 kt
- Ground Speed: 340 kt
- Distance: 280 NGM

How can we use the chart in order to calculate the NAM?

options.text: Enter the graph with the average TAS. Then, travel horizontally left to intersect the wind component. Then, travel vertically up to intersect the appropriate ground distance grid line. Finally, travel horizontally right to read the air distance.

Enter the graph with the ground distance.  Then, travel horizontally left to intersect the wind component. Then, travel vertically up to intersect the appropriate average TAS grid line. Finally, travel horizontally right to read the air distance.

Enter the graph with the wind component. Then, travel horizontally left to intersect the average TAS. Then, travel vertically up to intersect the appropriate ground distance grid line. Finally, travel horizontally left to read the air distance.

Enter the graph with the ground speed. Then, travel horizontally left to intersect the wind component. Then, travel vertically up to intersect the appropriate ground distance grid line. Finally, travel horizontally right to read the air distance.

variant.question: Conversion of fuel volume to mass

options.text: may be done by using standard fuel density values as specified by the Operations Manual, if the actual fuel density is not known.
must be done by using standard fuel density values as specified in EASA AIR OPS.
must be done by using actual measured fuel density values.
must be done using fuel density values of 0.79 for JP 1 and 0.76 for JP 4 as specified in EASA AIR OPS.

at least equivalent to 45 minutes flying time.
laid down by the operator, with the quantity being specified in the operating manual.
at least equivalent to the quantity required to fly to another aerodrome in the event that weather conditions so require.

variant.question: You are flying a VFR flight and you must fly at 150 kt IAS. The weather forecast announces that the visibility at the destination might drop below 5 000 m. What would you do?

options.text: Request to divert to your alternate and amend your flight plan.
Hold until weather conditions improve and then proceed to the destination.
Continue the flight as planned assuming that visibility will not drop below 1 500 m.

options.text: To fly to the destination, including one missed approach at the DA, then a flight to one of the two selected alternate airports requiring the most fuel and then for another 30 minutes flying + contingency fuel.
Planning an IFR flight to an airport without sufficient weather service is not allowed.
To fly to the destination, including one missed approach at the DA, then a flight to the alternate airport and then for another 45 minutes flying + contingency fuel.
To fly to the destination and then to fly for another 45 minutes in a holding at 1 500 feet AGL + contingency fuel.

Minimum planned take-off fuel is 160 kg. This amount includes a fuel reserve which equals to 30% of the trip fuel. Assume the groundspeed on this trip is constant. When the aeroplane has done half the distance the remaining fuel is 70 kg. Is diversion to a nearby alternate necessary?

options.text: Diversion to a nearby alternate is necessary, because the remaining fuel is not sufficient.
Diversion to a nearby alternate is not necessary, because it is allowed to calculate without reserve fuel.
Diversion to a nearby alternate is not necessary, because the reserve fuel has not been used completely.
Diversion to a nearby alternate is necessary, unless the captain decides to continue on his own responsibility.

variant.question:
You have planned to fly from airport A to airport B, which is 460 NM away. After flying for 1 hour 11 minutes, covering 183 NM, your fuel remaining is 780 Ib plus reserves. Given the following information, and assumimng conditions remain the same, what will be the remaining fuel at airport B?

Wind: 30 Kt headwind
Trip Fuel: 1098 Ib

planned average fuel flow: 320 Ib / h

On approach, ATS informs you that you have to hold for 17 minutes, having a final reserve fuel for 30 minutes, an alternate fuel of 40 minutes and extra fuel for 10 minutes. What is the most legal and commercially possible option?

options.text: Immediately proceed to the alternate, leaving the 30 minutes of final reserve fuel intact and extra fuel on landing.
Hold 10 minutes to see effectively if it's a 17 minutes holding, and in case it is, proceed to the alternate, leaving the 30 minutes of final reserve fuel intact.
Declare immediately low on fuel so that ATC will give you priority to land.
